Award.AwardTitle: NSF/FDA Scholar in Residence Program on Characterization of Micro- and Nanostructured Titanium Oxide and Zirconium Oxide Surfaces for Improved Medical Implants

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
#1343533
Roger J. Narayan

Standard protein assays and analyses involving quartz crystal microbalance technology will be employed to qualitatively and quantitatively assess protein adsorption dynamics. The information obtained in these studies will serve as the basis for a material property-biological performance database, in which the associations among in vitro cell-material interaction, protein adsorption, and processing parameters will be considered. The database will be of fundamental value for regulatory decision-making in FDA-CDRH related to devices with titanium oxide or zirconium oxide surfaces. This research and education program is well-suited to goals of the Scholar-in-Residence program because it combines nanomaterials processing capabilities at the UNC/NCSU Department of Biomedical
Engineering with in vitro biological characterization capabilities at the CDRH. This program will involve graduate student and PI activities at the FDA White Oak campus over a two-year period.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this completed program, an additive manufacturing (3d printing) technique known as two photon polymerization was used to create small-scale structures with sub-micrometer spatial resolution from a biodegradable photoelastomer. Scaffolds with porosities of greater than 60% were created using this approach. Human bone marrow stromal cells grown on three-dimensional photoelastomer scaffolds showed higher growth and proliferation than two-dimensional structures. In addition, the three-dimensional scaffolds were shown to adsorb higher amounts of protein than two-dimensional structures. Zr-Si scaffolds with 150, 200, and 250 μm pore sizes were also created using two photon polymerization; these scaffolds were seeded with human adipose tissue derived stem cells as well as  human bone marrow stem cells. A tabletop biological study indicated that the Zr-Si scaffolds with the smallest pore size had the strongest matrix mineralization and calcium deposition levels. In addition, mesenchymal stem cells cultured on the scaffolds without osteogenic stimulation were shown to differentiate in an osteogenic lineage. Two graduate research assistants received training on biomaterials processing and characterization via this program. The results of this program were disseminated to the scientific community via conference presentations and journal papers. In addition, several tutorials on biomaterials and additive manufacturing were given to industrial partners and professional societies (e.g., the Society for Biomaterials).

 

 


Last Modified: 12/08/2015
Modified by: Roger J Narayan

Zr-Si scaffolds with 150, 200, and 250 μm pore sizes were also created using two photon polymerization; these scaffolds were seeded with human adipose tissue derived stem cells as well as human bone marrow stem cells. A tabletop biological study indicated that the Zr-Si scaffolds with the smallest pore size had the strongest matrix mineralization and calcium deposition levels. In addition, mesenchymal stem cells cultured on the scaffolds without osteogenic stimulation were shown to differentiate in an osteogenic lineage. Two graduate research assistants received training on biomaterials processing and characterization via this program. The results of this program were disseminated to the scientific community via conference presentations and journal papers. In addition, several tutorials on biomaterials and additive manufacturing were given to industrial partners and professional societies (e.g., the Society for Biomaterials).
